items.synopsis: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 3.7 per cent in July, surpassing most economists expectations. It comes as the local sharemarket is trading lower despite a flurry of earnings reports from some of Australia's biggest companies. Follow live.

title.children: Unemployment rate rises to 3.7pc in July, Telstra and Origin profits surge, ASX lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Diana Mousina, deputy chief economist at AMP, says the increase in the July unemployment rate is likely very welcome news to the Reserve Bank. She described the increase in the unemployment rate as "pay back" for strong jobs growth in recent months. "When you go through periods of extremely strong jobs growth, you can sometimes get these one-off prints that look negative and it does look negative because the headline pace of jobs growth actually went backwards, employment fell by nearly 15,000 over the month of July," she said. "The unemployment rate has gone up, but at the same time, the unemployment rate is extremely low at 3.7%. "It is still around that 50 year low, however, nevertheless, I think the Reserve Bank would be welcoming the data because, even though we don't want to see the unemployment rate rise too much, the purpose of tightening interest rates has been to slow economic growth and part of that, unfortunately, is g etting the unemployment rate up ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA would be 'welcoming' unemployment data, economist says

children.content: Diana Mousina
, deputy chief economist at AMP, says the increase in the July unemployment rate is likely very welcome news to the Reserve Bank.
She described the increase in the unemployment rate as "pay back" for strong jobs growth in recent months.
"When you go through periods of extremely strong jobs growth, you can sometimes get these one-off prints that look negative and it does look negative because the
headline pace of jobs growth actually went backwards
, employment fell by nearly 15,000 over the month of July," she said.
"The unemployment rate has gone up, but at the same time, the
unemployment rate is extremely low at 3.7%
"It is
still around that 50 year low
, however, nevertheless, I
think the Reserve Bank would be welcoming the data
because, even though we don't want to see the unemployment rate rise too much, the
purpose of tightening interest rates has been to slow economic growth
and part of that, unfortunately, is g
etting the unemployment rate up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Although the unemployment rate has increased slightly to 3.7% in July, the ABS says the labour market remains tight. Bjorn Jarvis, the head of labour statistics with the ABS, said although employment fell by 15,000 people in July, it is still substantially higher than this time last year. "The fall in employment follows an average monthly increase of around 42,000 people during the first half of this year. Employment is still around 387,000 people higher than last July ," he said. "July includes the school holidays, and we continue to see some changes around when people take their leave and start or leave a job. "It’s important to consider this when looking at month-to-month changes, compared with the usual seasonal pattern. The only other fall in employment in 2023 was in April, which also included school holidays. "While unemployment increased by 36,000 people in July, to 541,000, it was still around 172,000 lower than before the pandemic ." Mr Jarvis said the high participation rate of 66.8% coupled with an underemployment rate of 6.4% suggests the labour market is still experiencing tight conditions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: All signs point to a 'tight labour market' despite rise in unemployment, ABS says

children.content: Although the unemployment rate has increased slightly to 3.7% in July, the ABS says the
labour market remains tight
Bjorn Jarvis
, the head of labour statistics with the ABS, said although
employment fell by 15,000 people in July,
it is still substantially higher than this time last year.
"The fall in employment follows an average monthly increase of around 42,000 people during the first half of this year.
Employment is still around 387,000 people higher than last July
," he said.
"July includes the school holidays, and we continue to see some changes around when people take their leave and start or leave a job.

"It’s important to consider this when looking at month-to-month changes, compared with the usual seasonal pattern. The only other fall in employment in 2023 was in April, which also included school holidays.
"While
unemployment increased by 36,000 people in July, to 541,000, it was still around 172,000 lower than before the pandemic
Mr Jarvis said the
high participation rate of 66.8%
coupled with an underemployment rate of 6.4% suggests the labour market is still experiencing tight conditions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 3.7% in July, surprising economists. The latest data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) shows the number of unemployed people increased by 36,000, while the participation rate fell by 0.1 percentage point to 66.7%. Economists had expected the unemployment rate to increase to 3.6% in July, after it remained steady at 3.5% in June.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Unemployment rate rises to 3.7%

children.content: Australia's unemployment rate rose to 3.7% in July, surprising economists.
The latest data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) shows the number of unemployed people increased by 36,000, while the participation rate fell by 0.1 percentage point to 66.7%.
Economists had expected the unemployment rate to increase to 3.6% in July, after it remained steady at 3.5% in June.
